Award.AwardTitle: HSI Conference: Accelerating the Impact of HSI STEM Education and Research on Innovation Ecosystems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The National Science Foundation (NSF) Dear Colleague Letter NSF 17-092: Improving Undergraduate STEM Education in Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSIs) calls for projects to support conferences that will identify the most critical challenges and opportunities regarding undergraduate science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education at HSIs, and potential actionable solutions that fall within NSF's mission, policies, and practices. In response to this call, the University of Puerto Rico-Mayag√ºez (UPRM) will host the HSI Conference: Accelerating the Impact of HSI STEM Education and Research on Innovation Ecosystems, in cooperation with other HSIs in Puerto Rico, as well as partners in the commercial economy. The conference will be held in October or November of 2018 and will to seek to expand active learning opportunities for undergraduate populations at HSIs by linking these students with mentors from both the commercial and knowledge economies. The incorporation of undergraduate experiential learning is an essential part of motivating students at HSIs to become "do-ers" in the realm of entrepreneurship and technology, and will contribute to increased persistence of students toward 4-year degrees at HSIs. These new networks of collaboration will also increase the impact of HSIs on innovation ecosystems. This conference is necessary due to (1) the density of HSIs in Puerto Rico, which is home to 70 institutions with over 150,000 total students, and (2) the need to expand the entrepreneurship and innovation efforts at UPRM to all institutions, especially given the current economic circumstances of the island.

The 2-day conference, in addition to pre- and post-conference meet-ups, will bring together an estimated 150 participants that include HSI education and research leaders, current and potential entrepreneurs, corporate and industry representatives, university administrators, invited guest speakers, undergraduate students, and NSF representatives to reflect on and discuss emerging effective strategies for encouraging links between university and industry, with the important component of undergraduate involvement. The activities will provide ample opportunity for interaction among participants of all backgrounds and levels--including invited undergraduate students--during poster sessions, panel discussions, and invited presentations. This interaction is essential to fully understand the challenges of establishing partnerships between university and industry, and how innovation ecosystems can improve STEM education at HSIs. The conference outcome will be a blueprint for developing innovation ecosystems at HSIs and the establishment of a regional hub for this initiative.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In response to the NSF Dear Colleague Letter: Improving Undergraduate STEM Education in Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSIs), the Accelerating the Impact of HSI STEM Education and Research on Innovation Ecosystems conference was held in Mayaguez on November 8 & 9, 2018 providing a snapshot of STEM education in Puerto Rico. The conference brought together 185 students and faculty participants from 37 HSI institutions, and the pre-conference NSF grant writing workshop included 49 participants. This high participation was the result of promotional and administrative efforts by the talented undergraduate students who worked in the project. 

The conference started with a poster session that allowed all attendees to meet with students participating in research and active learning projects at the HSIs. The conference received the full support of the following groups at the University of Puerto Rico at Mayaguez (UPRM):  the E-Ship network, the Research & Development Center, the Graduate Research and Innovation Center (GRIC), the Professional Enrichment Center (CEP), Research Academy for Faculty and Postdoctoral Fellows, Center for Business and Economic Development. The support of the Pontifical Catholic University of Puerto Rico which hosted the pre-conference NSF grant writing workshop is also acknowledged.

This was the only HSI conference held in Puerto Rico to inform on the design of the new Hispanic Service Institutions (HSI) program providing the following input:   

Intellectual Merit: 

1. There are many programs and opportunities to improve STEM education on our island. Students from the smaller HSI often participate in programs housed at the larger HSI. These programs are not limited to federally funded projects. One example is the Amgen BioTalents program housed at UPR-Mayaguez, which is also open to students from all of Puerto Rico's institutions. This program includes workshops and conferences on biotechnology that are offered throughout the island. The Amgen BioTalents program is well-known by the majority of smaller HSIs which encourage their students to participate. However, many more initiatives can be developed. 

2.  The innovation and entrepreneurship activities at UPR-Mayaguez, Universidad Ana G. Mendez, Universidad del Sagrado Corazon, and Inter American University of Puerto Rico at San German Campus, are examples of active learning available to both STEM and non-STEM students.  There are many ideas from the innovation and entrepreneurship process that can be applied to STEM education. As an example, the concept of mentorship has been recognized as crucial for the development of startups. The mentorship process has been studied in entrepreneurship, where different stages of business development require different mentors. The mentor for a startup will not necessarily be the mentor to help a company ready to export their products. In the same way, the mentorship that a STEM student needs when transitioning from a two-year to a four-year institution, will be different than when considering graduate studies. The mentorship that a first-year chemistry student needs will not be the same as that of the student that is near completing the B.S. degree. The concept of mentorship has evolved recently in the innovation and entrepreneurship domains, and there are many possibilities for its extension to STEM education.

3. Internships and active learning opportunities can be transformative for students.  These internships include Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) as well as industrial internships.

4. Capstone courses provide a unique opportunity for developing the industrial support of HSIs. Capstone courses help students understand how the science that they have learned is applied.

5. Our educational approaches must emphasize that students should not be afraid of new opportunities, whether these opportunities include accepting an internship far from home or starting a business.

Broader Impacts:

1. Communication and collaboration between the HSIs in the island increased as a result of the conference, and pre and post-conference activities. 

2. The Puerto Rico Science Technology and Research Trust participated in the conference, and played a key role in the team that created the Resuelvelo Boricua competition for intermediate school children. The HSI Conference was influential in their hiring of a new staff member, as STEM Program Manager. The Trust is now better positioned to team with local HSIs to seek new STEM educational opportunities, and is continuing with the Resuelvelo Boricua competition, and has expanded it to high school students.

3. The Strategic Doing Workshop was offered to local HSI, thanks to the support received from the Purdue Agile Strategy Lab and the Puerto Rico Science and Technology Research Trust. Strategic doing first asks "what could we do?", and requires that we look around at the assets that we have. Strategic Doing may be used to work with volunteers, and facilitate HSI work with community groups. Strategic Doing brings forth a live iterative process for planning and building trust that is essential for the success of projects between loosely connected networks. We will continue to use Strategic Doing to strengthen the contributions of our HSI.
